remixlab.proscene

Class KeyFrameInterpolator

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.proscene.KeyFrameInterpolator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Cloneable

    public class KeyFrameInterpolator
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable
    A keyFrame Catmull-Rom Frame interpolator.

    A KeyFrameInterpolator holds keyFrames (that define a path) and, optionally, a reference to a Frame of your application (which will be interpolated). In this case, when the user startInterpolation(), the KeyFrameInterpolator regularly updates the frame() position and orientation along the path.

    Here is a typical utilization example (see also the examples FrameInterpolation and CameraInterpolation):

    //PApplet.setup() should look like:
    size(640, 360, P3D);
    // The KeyFrameInterpolator kfi is given the Frame that it will drive over time.
    myFrame = new Frame()); kfi = new KeyFrameInterpolator( myFrame, this ); //or an anonymous Frame may also be given: kfi = new KeyFrameInterpolator( this );
    //By default the Frame is provided as a reference to the KeyFrameInterpolator} (see addKeyFrame(Frame) methods):
    kfi.addKeyFrame( new Frame( new PVector(1,0,0), new Quaternion() ) );
    kfi.addKeyFrame( new Frame( new PVector(2,1,0), new Quaternion() ) );
    // ...and so on for all the keyFrames.
    kfi.startInterpolation();

    //PApplet.draw() should look like:
    background(0);
    scene.beginDraw();
    pushMatrix();
    kfi.frame().applyTransformation(this);
    // Draw your object here. Its position and orientation are interpolated.
    popMatrix();
    scene.endDraw();

    The keyFrames are defined by a Frame and a time, expressed in seconds. Optionally, the Frame can be provided as a reference (see the addKeyFrame(Frame) methods). In this case, the path will automatically be updated when the Frame is modified.

    The time has to be monotonously increasing over keyFrames. When interpolationSpeed() equals 1.0 (default value), these times correspond to actual user's seconds during interpolation (provided that your main loop is fast enough). The interpolation is then real-time: the keyFrames will be reached at their keyFrameTime(int).

    Interpolation details

    When the user startInterpolation(), a timer is started which will update the frame()'s position and orientation every interpolationPeriod() milliseconds. This update increases the interpolationTime() by interpolationPeriod() * interpolationSpeed() milliseconds.

    Note that this mechanism ensures that the number of interpolation steps is constant and equal to the total path duration() divided by the interpolationPeriod() * interpolationSpeed(). This is especially useful for benchmarking or movie creation (constant number of snapshots).

    The interpolation is stopped when interpolationTime() is greater than the lastTime() (unless loopInterpolation() is true).

    Note that a Camera has Camera.keyFrameInterpolator(int), that can be used to drive the Camera along a path.

    Attention: If a Constraint is attached to the frame() (see Frame.constraint()), it should be deactivated before interpolationIsStarted(), otherwise the interpolated motion (computed as if there was no constraint) will probably be erroneous.

        Convenience constructor that simply calls this(scn, new Frame()).

        Creates an anonymous frame() to be interpolated by this KeyFrameInterpolator.

        See Also:
        KeyFrameInterpolator(Scene, Frame)

      • KeyFrameInterpolator

        public KeyFrameInterpolator(Scene scn,
                    Frame frame)
        Creates a KeyFrameInterpolator, with frame as associated frame(). The p3d object will be used if drawPath(int, int, float) is called.

        The frame() can be set or changed using setFrame(Frame).

        interpolationTime(), interpolationSpeed() and interpolationPeriod() are set to their default values.

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        public KeyFrameInterpolator clone()
        Implementation of the clone method.

        The method performs a deep copy of the all the KeyFrameInterpolator KeyFrames.

        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • setFrame

        public void setFrame(Frame f)
        Sets the frame() associated to the KeyFrameInterpolator.

      • frame

        public Frame frame()
        Returns the associated Frame that is interpolated by the KeyFrameInterpolator.

        When interpolationIsStarted(), this Frame's position and orientation will regularly be updated by a timer, so that they follow the KeyFrameInterpolator path.

        Set using setFrame(Frame) or with the KeyFrameInterpolator constructor.

      • numberOfKeyFrames

        public int numberOfKeyFrames()
        Returns the number of keyFrames used by the interpolation. Use addKeyFrame(Frame) to add new keyFrames.

      • interpolationTime

        public float interpolationTime()
        Returns the current interpolation time (in seconds) along the KeyFrameInterpolator path.

        This time is regularly updated when interpolationIsStarted(). Can be set directly with setInterpolationTime(float) or interpolateAtTime(float).

      • interpolationSpeed

        public float interpolationSpeed()
        Returns the current interpolation speed.

        Default value is 1.0f, which means keyFrameTime(int) will be matched during the interpolation (provided that your main loop is fast enough).

        A negative value will result in a reverse interpolation of the keyFrames.

        See Also:
        interpolationPeriod()

      • interpolationPeriod

        public int interpolationPeriod()
        Returns the current interpolation period, expressed in milliseconds. The update of the frame() state will be done by a timer at this period when interpolationIsStarted().

        This period (multiplied by interpolationSpeed()) is added to the interpolationTime() at each update, and the frame() state is modified accordingly (see interpolateAtTime(float)). Default value is 40 milliseconds.

        See Also:
        setInterpolationPeriod(int)

      • loopInterpolation

        public boolean loopInterpolation()
        Returns true when the interpolation is played in an infinite loop.

        When false (default), the interpolation stops when interpolationTime() reaches firstTime() (with negative interpolationSpeed()) or lastTime().

        interpolationTime() is otherwise reset to firstTime() (+ interpolationTime() - lastTime()) (and inversely for negative interpolationSpeed()) and interpolation continues.

      • setInterpolationTime

        public void setInterpolationTime(float time)
        Sets the interpolationTime().

        Attention: The frame() state is not affected by this method. Use this function to define the starting time of a future interpolation (see startInterpolation()). Use interpolateAtTime(float) to actually interpolate at a given time.

      • setInterpolationSpeed

        public void setInterpolationSpeed(float speed)
        Sets the interpolationSpeed(). Negative or null values are allowed.

      • setInterpolationPeriod

        public void setInterpolationPeriod(int myPeriod)
        Sets the interpolationPeriod(). Should positive.

      • setLoopInterpolation

        public void setLoopInterpolation()
        Convenience function that simply calls setLoopInterpolation(true).

      • setLoopInterpolation

        public void setLoopInterpolation(boolean loop)
        Sets the loopInterpolation() value.

      • interpolationIsStarted

        public boolean interpolationIsStarted()
        Returns true when the interpolation is being performed. Use startInterpolation(), stopInterpolation() or toggleInterpolation() to modify this state.

      • toggleInterpolation

        public void toggleInterpolation()
        Calls startInterpolation() or stopInterpolation(), depending on interpolationIsStarted().

      • startInterpolation

        public void startInterpolation()
        Convenience function that simply calls startInterpolation(-1).
        See Also:
        startInterpolation(int)

      • startInterpolation

        public void startInterpolation(int myPeriod)
        Starts the interpolation process.

        A timer is started with an interpolationPeriod() period that updates the frame()'s position and orientation. interpolationIsStarted() will return true until stopInterpolation() or toggleInterpolation() is called.

        If period is positive, it is set as the new interpolationPeriod(). The previous interpolationPeriod() is used otherwise (default).

        If interpolationTime() is larger than lastTime(), interpolationTime() is reset to firstTime() before interpolation starts (and inversely for negative interpolationSpeed().

        Use setInterpolationTime(float) before calling this method to change the starting interpolationTime().

        Attention: The keyFrames must be defined (see addKeyFrame(Frame, float)) before you startInterpolation(), or else the interpolation will naturally immediately stop.

      • stopInterpolation

        public void stopInterpolation()
        Stops an interpolation started with startInterpolation(). See interpolationIsStarted() and toggleInterpolation().

      • resetInterpolation

        public void resetInterpolation()
        Stops the interpolation and resets interpolationTime() to the firstTime().

        If desired, call interpolateAtTime(float) after this method to actually move the frame() to firstTime().

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame)
        Convenience function that simply calls addKeyFrame(frame, false).
        See Also:
        addKeyFrame(Frame, boolean)

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame,
               boolean setRef)
        Appends a new keyFrame to the path.

        Same as addKeyFrame(Frame, float, boolean), except that the keyFrameTime(int) is set to the previous keyFrameTime(int) plus one second (or 0.0 if there is no previous keyFrame).

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame,
               float time)
        Convenience function that simply calls addKeyFrame(frame, time, false).
        See Also:
        addKeyFrame(Frame, float, boolean)

      • addKeyFrame

        public void addKeyFrame(Frame frame,
               float time,
               boolean setRef)
        Appends a new keyFrame to the path, with its associated time (in seconds).

        When setRef is false the keyFrame is added by value, meaning that the path will use the current frame state.

        When setRef is true the keyFrame is given as a reference to a Frame, which will be connected to the KeyFrameInterpolator: when frame is modified, the KeyFrameInterpolator path is updated accordingly. This allows for dynamic paths, where keyFrame can be edited, even during the interpolation. null frame references are silently ignored. The keyFrameTime(int) has to be monotonously increasing over keyFrames.

      • deletePath

        public void deletePath()
        Removes all keyFrames from the path. Calls removeFramesFromMouseGrabberPool(). The numberOfKeyFrames() is set to 0.
        See Also:
        removeFramesFromMouseGrabberPool()

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath()
        Convenience function that simply calls drawPath(1, 6, 100)

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(float scale)
        Convenience function that simply calls drawPath(1, 6, scale)

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(int mask,
            int nbFrames)
        Convenience function that simply calls drawPath(mask, nbFrames, 100)

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(int mask,
            int nbFrames,
            float scale)
        Draws the path used to interpolate the frame().

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), a camera representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), an oriented axis is regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and cameras
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axis

        In the case where camera or axis is drawn, nbFrames controls the number of objects (axis or camera) drawn between two successive keyFrames. When nbFrames = 1, only the path KeyFrames are drawn. nbFrames = 2 also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30. nbFrames should divide 30 so that an object is drawn for each KeyFrame. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the camera and axis drawing. A value of Scene.radius() should give good results.

      • keyFrame

        public Frame keyFrame(int index)
        Returns the Frame associated with the keyFrame at index index.

        See also keyFrameTime(int). index has to be in the range 0..numberOfKeyFrames()-1.

        Note: If this keyFrame was defined using a reference to a Frame (see addKeyFrame(Frame, float, boolean) the current referenced Frame state is returned.

      • keyFrameTime

        public float keyFrameTime(int index)
        Returns the time corresponding to the index keyFrame. index has to be in the range 0..numberOfKeyFrames()-1.
        See Also:
        keyFrame(int)

      • duration

        public float duration()
        Returns the duration of the KeyFrameInterpolator path, expressed in seconds.

        Simply corresponds to lastTime() - firstTime(). Returns 0.0 if the path has less than 2 keyFrames.

        See Also:
        keyFrameTime(int)

      • firstTime

        public float firstTime()
        Returns the time corresponding to the first keyFrame, expressed in seconds.

        Returns 0.0 if the path is empty.

        See Also:
        lastTime(), duration(), keyFrameTime(int)

      • lastTime

        public float lastTime()
        Returns the time corresponding to the last keyFrame, expressed in seconds.

        See Also:
        firstTime(), duration(), keyFrameTime(int)

      • updateSplineCache

        public void updateSplineCache()

      • interpolateAtTime

        public void interpolateAtTime(float time)
        Interpolate frame() at time time (expressed in seconds). interpolationTime() is set to time and frame() is set accordingly.

        If you simply want to change interpolationTime() but not the frame() state, use setInterpolationTime(float) instead.
